qas.question: What was the name of the first self-sustained man-made nuclear reaction?

plausible_answers.text: tested how life originated on early Earth

qas.question: Why was the Kleitman-Aserinsky experiment conducted?
When was the Miller-Urey experiment conducted?
What kind of sleep was discovered at the U of C in 1947?
What was the experiment that tested early life on Mars called?
What gave way to the Chicago school of psychology?

context: The University of Chicago has been the site of some important experiments and academic movements. In economics, the university has played an important role in <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>shaping ideas about the free market<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> and is the namesake of the Chicago school of economics, the school of economic thought supported by Milton Friedman and other economists. The <b8_0>university's sociology department<b8_0/> was the first independent sociology department in the United States and gave birth to the Chicago school of sociology. In physics, the university was the site of the <a1_0><a1_1><a2_2>Chicago Pile-1<a2_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> (the first self-sustained man-made nuclear reaction, part of the Manhattan Project), of Robert Millikan's oil-drop experiment that calculated the charge of the electron, and of the development of radiocarbon dating by Willard F. Libby in 1947. The chemical experiment that <b4_0>tested how life originated on early Earth<b4_0/>, the <a2_0><a2_1><b7_0>Miller–Urey experiment<b7_0/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, was conducted at the university. <b6_0>REM<b6_0/> sleep was discovered at the university in <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b5_0>1953<b5_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> by Nathaniel Kleitman and Eugene Aserinsky.
